newsitem.title: USA: Former Olicom A/S executive settles with SEC.
newsitem.headline: Former Olicom A/S executive settles with SEC.

text.p: A federal judge ordered a former Danish company executive and a Luxembourg company to pay $386,109 in penalities to settle insider trading charges, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

Without admitting or denying allegations, Michael Jonsson of Hellerup, Denmark, and Objective Invest Holding S.A. agreed to pay a total of $186,849.50 in insider trading-derived profits, $12,409.87 in prejudgment interest and a civil penalty of $186,849.50, the regulatory agency said.
U.S. District Judge Richard Owen in New York on Tuesday issued the final judgment, which also requires Jonsson and Objective to cooperate with the commission's investigation.
The commission said it could not provide any further details on the probe.

The commission's October 1996 civil lawsuit against Jonsson, a former Olicom executive, alleged he traded on confidential information that Olicom was going to report operating losses for the first quarter of 1996. The announcement was made April 2, 1996.

The commission alleged that Jonsson and Objective, a privately held Luxembourg corporation whose account he controls, sold 28,000 share of Olicom's common stock and bought a total of 800 Olicom put options, which give the holder the right to sell the stock at a certain price.

Jonsson and Objective Invest avoided losses of about $88,000 by selling Olicom stock, and reaped a profit of about $99,000 through the exercise of the put options and accompanying transactions in Olicom, the commission alleged.

At the time of the trading, Jonsson was vice president, international sales for Olicom, a Lyngby, Denmark-based company that develops and markets computer products. Its U.S. subsidiary is in Plano, Texas.
Jonsson's New York attorney declined to comment on the settlement. Jonsson could not be reached for comment.
